comments:
build I20050331-0800

- was launching my usual self-hosting workspace, but had changed the list of
plug-ins to select o.e.ui.workbench from the install (default PDE target)
instead of the workspace (in order to test what's in the build, rather than what
I have loaded)
- it failed with:

So it looks like o.e.ui.workbench is missing.
Checked out the config area (under the PDE metadata area), and it looks OK to me.
The log doesn't give any explanation for why o.e.ui.workbench was missing.

Created an attachment (id=19420)
Zip of config area for the launch config

Having the launch config clear the config area did not change things (I was
previously passing -clean).

In my workspace, I have the following loaded: osgi, core, swt, jface, workbench,
text, pde core, pde ui, update scheduler, update ui (all up to date), and a
bunch of extraneous projects.

In the launch config, I was previously using "Launch with all...".
This worked OK.

Then I checked "Choose plug-ins..." and unchecked o.e.ui.workbench from the
workspace, and checked it under External Plug-ins.  Validate Plug-in Set found
no problems.
This caused the problem here.

I tried closing all the extraneous projects, but that did not change things.

If I switch o.e.ui.workbench back to the workspace, it works OK (with "Choose
plug-ins..." still checked).

the platform.xml references the ui.workbench from the target as it should.
the config.ini and dev.properties have the correct content.

Moving to Platform/Runtime.

I think this is a regression in M6, possibly due to the jar support.
I was able to do this kind of thing successfully when testing M5.
*** Bug 89679 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***

Stefan is also seeing this. We could verify that the manifest generated for
org.eclipse.ui.workbench is not exporting any packages, although the class path
is correct. This causes the AbstractUIPlugin not found error.

I am able to reproduce with just o.e.osgi and o.e.ui.workbench in my 
workspace.  Still investigating what is going on ...

The issue is actually in Core land. The plug-in converter is getting confused by
running in dev mode with plug-ins that come from the target.

The dev.properties for the configuration is not being updated to properly 
reflect the selected plugins from the workspace.  If I uncheck 
o.e.ui.workbench from my workspace and select the o.e.ui.workbench from the 
install (default PDE target) then the dev.properties for the configuration is 
not updated accordingly.  I have the following in my configuration 
dev.properties:

#
#Thu Mar 31 14:10:34 CST 2005
org.eclipse.osgi=bin
org.eclipse.ui.workbench=bin
@ignoredot@=true

PDE is telling the runtime (plugin converter) to ingoredot for all plugins it 
specifies.  It is still specifying o.e.ui.workbench even though we are no 
longer loading it from the workspace.  This causes the converter to ignoredot 
which causes the ui.workbench to not export any packages because it only 
has '.' on its classpath.

Clearing the configuration area seems to fix the problem.  This is because PDE 
generates the correct dev.properties for the new configuration.
I run with "Clear configuration area" checked and it keeps failing.

On the drive home, I realized that this could be due to the new semantics 
of '.' in the dev.properties.
As mentioned above, I was clearing the config too and it was still happening.

I understand.  as long as PDE generates this @ignoredot@=true and lists 
org.eclipse.ui.workbench in the same file, you will never be able to launch 
even if you clear:
1. you workspace
2. your configuration area
3. your desk
4. a check

The dev.properties is that powerful.

Opened bug 89890 against JDT/Debug, triggered by the same scenario: you have a
plug-in in your workspace, but user selects to load it from the target.
Fixed.

traces.message: The activator org.eclipse.ui.internal.ide.IDEWorkbenchPlugin for bundle org.eclipse.ui.ide is invalid
